node.contents: If the pointer is word aligned, you want to steal the two **LSBs** not the two **MSBs**. Most pointers are word aligned. I have no idea how you'd get to the bit-representation of a pointer in Java, though.

node.contents: Note that you can probably get away with "stealing" a few bits on the low end on many (but not all) platforms, but taking from the high end is a lot iffier. And either way you're going to run afoul of GC, even if you manage to not simply break ordinary execution.

astNode.text: Note that you can probably get away with "stealing" a few bits on the low end on many (but not all) platforms, but taking from the high end is a lot iffier. And either way you're going to run afoul of GC, even if you manage to not simply break ordinary execution.

node.contents: (New objects will normally be aligned on a 8 or 16-byte boundary. However, the JVM could do goofy things with Integer objects, eg, and "allocate" them entirely in the reference. And some JVMs (so-called 32/64 implementations) use 4-byte references but shift over 4 bits to access 36 bits of address space.)

astNode.text: (New objects will normally be aligned on a 8 or 16-byte boundary. However, the JVM could do goofy things with Integer objects, eg, and "allocate" them entirely in the reference. And some JVMs (so-called 32/64 implementations) use 4-byte references but shift over 4 bits to access 36 bits of address space.)

node.contents: "Java RTTI" is kind of a meaningless term. And to the extent that it has any meaning, it has essentially nothing to do with synchronization.

astNode.text: "Java RTTI" is kind of a meaningless term. And to the extent that it has any meaning, it has essentially nothing to do with synchronization.

node.contents: I just solved this problem using Java RTTI. Instead of 2 bits, I had 4 subclasses of type "00", "01", "10" & "11" and a common superclass. During runtime, I identify the bits based on the class type. It gave me 2X speedup.

astNode.text: I just solved this problem using Java RTTI. Instead of 2 bits, I had 4 subclasses of type "00", "01", "10" & "11" and a common superclass. During runtime, I identify the bits based on the class type. It gave me 2X speedup.

elements.contents: public class Node { long key; long value; Node lchild; // format is flag1,flag2,address Node rchild; // format is flag1,flag2,address } public void createNode() { Node n1 = new Node(); //this should create a node with format 0,0,address1 } public void setFlag1(Node n1) { Now the new address should be in format 1,0,address1 } public void setFlag2(Node n1) { Now the new address should be in format 0,1,address1 }

node.contents: To take bits out of those available for object reference variables will require creating your own JVM.

astNode.text: To take bits out of those available for object reference variables will require creating your own JVM.

node.contents: You will first have to assure that the bits are not actually used (eg, by taking the low-order bits in a reference when the JVM always aligns objects on a 16-byte boundary). But some JVMs use all bits of a 32-bit reference.

astNode.text: You will first have to assure that the bits are not actually used (eg, by taking the low-order bits in a reference when the JVM always aligns objects on a 16-byte boundary). But some JVMs use all bits of a 32-bit reference.

node.contents: Next, you'll have to inject code every time a reference is loaded to clear those bits before accessing the associated object.

astNode.text: Next, you'll have to inject code every time a reference is loaded to clear those bits before accessing the associated object.

node.contents: Then you'll have to do the same for the garbage collector.

astNode.text: Then you'll have to do the same for the garbage collector.

node.contents: The best suggestion I can give you for working in Java would be to do your bit-twiddling on array indices rather than addresses, since Java does not expose addresses.

astNode.text: The best suggestion I can give you for working in Java would be to do your bit-twiddling on array indices rather than addresses, since Java does not expose addresses.

node.contents: This is impossible without implementing your own JVM which supports this kind of operations and deals with the flag bits properly, e.g. when doing GC (all references need to be identified at this point and moving collectors will need to change them). Even then, this is against the design principles of Java which do not include explicit dereferencing or pointer arithmetic (which I would count changing bits in a reference and masking them for dereferencing towards).

astNode.text: This is impossible without implementing your own JVM which supports this kind of operations and deals with the flag bits properly, e.g. when doing GC (all references need to be identified at this point and moving collectors will need to change them). Even then, this is against the design principles of Java which do not include explicit dereferencing or pointer arithmetic (which I would count changing bits in a reference and masking them for dereferencing towards).

node.contents: Instead, I would recommend you to create a new composite Edge type of the flags and the Node:

astNode.text: Instead, I would recommend you to create a new composite Edge type of the flags and the Node:

elements.contents: public class Node { long key; long value; Child lchild; // child = node reference + flags Child rchild; } // this is the edge type which should also be used to reference the root node with flags public class Child { Node child; BitSet flags; public Child(Node node) { this.child = node; this.flags = new BitSet(2); // we initialize the flags with 00 } public void setFlag(int index) { this.flags.set(index); // index would be 0 or 1 here for the two flags } public boolean isFlagSet(int index) { return this.flags.get(index); // index would be 0 or 1 here for the two flags } }

comments.text: // child = node reference + flags Child rchild; } // this is the edge type which should also be used to reference the root node with flags public class Child { Node child; BitSet flags; public Child(Node node) { this.child = node; this.flags = new BitSet(2); // we initialize the flags with 00 } public void setFlag(int index) { this.flags.set(index); // index would be 0 or 1 here for the two flags } public boolean isFlagSet(int index) { return this.flags.get(index); // index would be 0 or 1 here for the two flags } }

node.contents: Copying an extract from the book "The art of multiprocessor programming" p.215 by Maurice Herlihy and Nir Shavit:

astNode.text: Copying an extract from the book "The art of multiprocessor programming" p.215 by Maurice Herlihy and Nir Shavit:

node.contents: As described in detail in Pragma 9.8.1, an AtomicMarkableReference object encapsulates both a reference to an object of type T and a Boolean mark. These fields can be atomically updated, either together or individually. We make each node’s next field an AtomicMarkableReference. Thread A logically removes currA by setting the mark bit in the node’s next field, and shares the physical removal with other threads performing add() or remove(): as each thread traverses the list, it cleans up the list by physically removing (using compareAndSet()) any marked nodes it encounters. In other words, threads performing add() and remove() do not traverse marked nodes, they remove them before continuing. The contains() method remains the same as in the LazyList algorithm, traversing all nodes whether they are marked or not, and testing if an item is in the list based on its key and mark.

astNode.text: As described in detail in Pragma 9.8.1, an AtomicMarkableReference object encapsulates both a reference to an object of type T and a Boolean mark. These fields can be atomically updated, either together or individually. We make each node’s next field an AtomicMarkableReference. Thread A logically removes currA by setting the mark bit in the node’s next field, and shares the physical removal with other threads performing add() or remove(): as each thread traverses the list, it cleans up the list by physically removing (using compareAndSet()) any marked nodes it encounters. In other words, threads performing add() and remove() do not traverse marked nodes, they remove them before continuing. The contains() method remains the same as in the LazyList algorithm, traversing all nodes whether they are marked or not, and testing if an item is in the list based on its key and mark.

node.contents: Basically, Unsafe lets you manipulate data in an object without following Java's usual type safety rules. This is risky, and you could easily cause some pretty nasty bugs - but on the flipside you can get some great performance. Normally I would advise against it.

astNode.text: Basically, Unsafe lets you manipulate data in an object without following Java's usual type safety rules. This is risky, and you could easily cause some pretty nasty bugs - but on the flipside you can get some great performance. Normally I would advise against it.

node.contents: Having said that, if you are implementing a binary search tree I'd suggest looking at immutable persistent data structures. Advantages of these include:

astNode.text: Having said that, if you are implementing a binary search tree I'd suggest looking at immutable persistent data structures. Advantages of these include:

node.contents:
• They are thread safe by definition because of immutability
  • They require no locks
  • The ability to do structural sharing will be a big performance win once you start doing more complicated stuff (e.g. snapshotting of subtrees) - basically you avoid the need to take defensive copies.

astNode.text:
• They are thread safe by definition because of immutability
  • They require no locks
  • The ability to do structural sharing will be a big performance win once you start doing more complicated stuff (e.g. snapshotting of subtrees) - basically you avoid the need to take defensive copies.
